> As does the SCT when the number of species is fixed.  But it sounds
> like your approach alters the threshold based on the amount of
> topological variation in the population...is that right?

Correct.

> Wouldn't you get similar results by having a floating SCT value and a
> fixed number of species?

Very similar. But there are some differences. Under this method there does
exist a kind of "optimal" number of species, but it can be changed. I
think this method allows for a little more flexibility than just clamping
the number of species. Also it responds better to "explosions of
topological innovation" ... i.e. if there is a lot of topological
innovation around a certain epoch, things will still be speciated
correctly, even if the optimal number of species is exceeded.

Experimentally it is mostly the same, it just frees me from having to set
the number of species explicitly.
